translation.en: -[birds chirping] -[sirens wailing in distance]
[Chris Colbert] ♪ Whoop! Whoop! It's the sound of the police ♪
♪ Whoop! Whoop! The belly of the beast ♪
I was a street kid, beating niggas up,
robbing people, stabbing people. I used to do all that. Carried a gun.
translation.ko: 도둑질하고 사람을 찌르고 총도 들고 온갖 짓을 했죠

translation.en: These people in the streets don't fight no more. They shoot you.
translation.ko: 이젠 사람들이 몸으로 안 싸우고 총을 쏴요

translation.en: That was the path, in the wrong direction.
♪ I ain't hating now We the next superstar boy ♪
The whole point of this sport is hit and not get hit.
translation.ko: 권투의 핵심은 맞지 않고 때리는 거예요

translation.en: Don't take no unnecessary punishment.
It's how long you can last. And, you know, how smart you can be in this game.
translation.ko: 머리를 잘 써서 오래 버텨야 해요

translation.en: [Cam F. Awesome] You don't need to be angry to fight.
Boxing, to me, is a tactical game.
Everything I do is based off logic.
It's, "Can I be smarter?" And manning up when it needs to be done.
But there's so many variables in boxing
that there's really no such thing as a right thing to do,
just a bunch of wrongs.
[Peter Quillin] To express myself is through a fight.
I watch for your mistakes, try to beat you to the punch.
There's no formula to winning.
It's a window I'm looking for.
That window closes in one second.
[announcer] Three two-minute rounds. In the gold corner...
-Jay Bulger! -[crowd cheering]
My name is Jay Bulger, and boxing saved my life.
translation.ko: 제 이름은 제이 벌저예요 권투가 제 목숨을 살렸죠

translation.en: I was just an angry kid, getting into fights,
translation.ko: 어릴 땐 분노에 차서 싸움만 했습니다

translation.en: headed in the wrong direction.
Then, I walked into a boxing gym,
connected with the trainer,
and I found something to fight for.
To become a New York City Golden Gloves champion.
translation.ko: 뉴욕 골든 글러브스 챔피언이 되는 거였죠

translation.en: It was so simple and honest.
You get up into that ring...
and you're exposed.
-You find out what you're really made of. -[crowd cheering]
Years later, I've set out to capture the state of boxing in America.
translation.ko: 몇 년 뒤, 미국 권투의 현주소를 알아보기로 했습니다

translation.en: Only to find that so many of the gyms I boxed at...
have closed their doors.
Today, most kids would rather play basketball or football.
translation.ko: 요즘 애들은 농구나 축구를 더 좋아하죠

translation.en: Do anything but get in the ring.
You can't play boxing. It's not a game.
It's a test...
of how much you can hit...
without being hit.
The brutality is inherent...
to both its appeal and to its demise.
Now, there was a time in America when everybody loved boxing.
When fighters like Dempsey, Louis, Marciano, Ali and Tyson
were kings of the world.
So, for the American fighters who still believe in boxing,
translation.ko: 지금도 권투의 맥을 잇는 미국 선수들은

translation.en: why do they do it,
and what does it take to be champion?
All I know is that there will always be the next kid
who needs to fight their way out...
by stepping into the squared circle.
translation.ko: 자신의 길을 찾는 아이가 나오리라는 사실이죠

translation.en: [Colbert] I don't know what I would be doing if not for boxing.
translation.ko: 권투가 아니었다면 뭘 하고 있을지 모르겠어요

translation.en: I think I would have been dead or some shit.
I've been through shoot-outs. I've been through shelter homes.
My life was never easy. My life's still not easy up to this day.
translation.ko: 삶이 쉬웠던 적이 없죠 지금도 그래요

translation.en: -[woman] Get out. -Yeah, a'ight.
[woman] Get the fuck out.
[Colbert] Shit is hard, like... I don't let it stress me, though.
Not one of them people that let that shit bother me.
I take that shit and I use it as a motivation
to push me to be better at what I do.
I'ma be the big champion of the world
and take my family out of the hood and get them into a better place.
translation.ko: 가족을 데리고 더 좋은 곳으로 이사할 거예요

translation.en: [Bulger] Eighteen-year-old Christopher "Lil B-Hop" Colbert
is the best amateur boxer in New York City.
He rides the subway, two hours, every day to Flatbush, Brooklyn,
translation.ko: 2시간 동안 지하철을 타고 매일 브루클린으로 향하죠

translation.en: so he can train at the very last free boxing gym in New York City,
translation.ko: 뉴욕에 하나 남은 무료 권투 체육관에서 훈련합니다

translation.en: Atlas Cops and Kids.
[man] Let's go.
I'm ready.
Welcome to Brooklyn.
[Pat Russo] What we do with the kids, it's quiet prevention.
If the kids are in the gym,
and they're off the streets and they're staying in school...
They'll all tell you that the program's changed their life.
translation.ko: 다들 이 프로그램으로 인생이 바뀌었다고 해요

translation.en: It cost us about $50,000 to run one gym, to run one gym.
translation.ko: 체육관 하나 운영하는 데 5만 달러가 들어요 “패트 루소 경사, 관장”

translation.en: It'll cost $67,000
to put one kid in jail for a year in this city...
which is insanity.
[coach] Come on, baby, come on. Let's go.
These boxing gyms that created legends and boxing champions...
translation.ko: 이런 체육관에서 챔피언이 많이 탄생했는데 “슈가 레이 레너드 권투 명예의 전당 등극”

translation.en: seem to no longer exist.
I find it quite disturbing because boxing has given me so much.
translation.ko: 많이 신경 쓰였죠 제겐 의미가 크거든요

translation.en: It has given me such a life.
And if it wasn't for boxing, I'd, more than likely...
I would be in jail or dead.
[Bulger] Sergeant Russo, Teddy Atlas, and the NYPD Boxing Team
translation.ko: 루소 경사와 테디 아틀라스 뉴욕 경찰 권투팀은

translation.en: understand that every kid kept off the street
is a kid who doesn't end up in trouble.
translation.ko: 문제도 사라진다는 것을 잘 알고 있습니다

translation.en: And so, when the Police Athletic League, the staple community boxing gyms,
translation.ko: 경찰 체육 연맹에서 운영하던 권투 체육관이

translation.en: shut down their programs,
they started Atlas Cops and Kids,
translation.ko: 이들은 아틀라스 캅스 앤 키즈를 시작했고

translation.en: which has quickly become one of the most successful boxing programs in the country.
translation.ko: 전국의 권투 프로그램 중 가장 큰 성공을 거뒀습니다

translation.en: Thank God for a program like that.
It takes a lot of those kids off the streets.
translation.ko: 우리 프로그램 덕분에 거리를 배회하던 애들이 많이 사라졌어요

translation.en: Within six years, we built eight national champions,
eight New York Golden Glove champions,
and now we've got a couple of pros, you know.
[Colbert] I'm 116 fights. 113-3.
I'm a four-time national champion.
A Golden Glove champion, ranked number one in the country.
I'm not letting nobody beat me.
One day, I'ma turn pro.
I'm destined to be world champion. I gotta be world champion.
Jab, jab!
B-Hop absolutely can become champion of the world.
translation.ko: B-홉은 분명 세계 챔피언이 될 거예요

translation.en: He's got a gift, he does.
He's got something special about him.
He has the potential, he has the talent.
But it's gonna be no cakewalk.
The name B-Hop, it came from the legend Bernard Hopkins.
translation.ko: 버나드 홉킨스 선수를 따라서 B-홉이라고 지었어요

translation.en: He was like me. He came off the streets, straight off the streets, winning.
He's the best, man. Just like me. You know how it is.
Biologically, he's not my son.
translation.ko: 실제 아들은 아니에요 “버나드 홉킨스 전 라이트 헤비급 챔피언”

translation.en: Because people were like, "Wait a minute, you got a son in Brooklyn?"
translation.ko: “버나드 홉킨스 전 라이트 헤비급 챔피언” 사람들이 브루클린에 애가 있느냐고 묻는데

translation.en: He's my son, but not of... You know what I mean.
Not of my son.
[Sosa] Once he stepped in the ring and learned how to fight,
he never had a fight in the street.
Five, six years he never had a fight in the street. But before that,
translation.ko: 5, 6년 동안 한 번도 그런 적 없죠

translation.en: every other weekend, every other week, fight, fight, fight.
Now he's good.
[Colbert] Me and Sosa been rocking since day one. He changed my life. A lot, a lot.
translation.ko: 첫날부터 함께한 소사 코치님은 제 인생을 바꿔놨어요

translation.en: He's like a father figure in my life.
You see this?
[Bulger] What's that?
Sosa Crew For Life.
You see it.
[Bulger] Who made that?
My dad.
It's a little rewarding, I mean, 'cause, you know, saying like... that I'm his dad.
I mean, it, um...
I'm making a difference, you know.
Everything on you, so you gotta pay for me,
-[chuckles] What? -Wayne...
...my girl, and then I'ma pay you back.
Your girl? Your girl makes more money than me.
translation.ko: 네 여자 친구가 나보다 돈 많이 벌겠다

translation.en: [Colbert] Nah, you crazy.
[Sosa] Boxing got him off the streets,
but I always tell him, "You got to be careful, man.
A lot of bad stuff happened in front of this building, you know, but...
translation.ko: 이 건물 앞에서 위험한 일이 많이 있었거든요

translation.en: They don't care if you fight or not.
Remember, a bullet is faster than your hands."
[Sosa] Yeah, that's how my day starts, man.
Get up at 5:30, get ready for work.
Be at work by 7:00, 7:10. Start work at 8:00.
We should be finished by 2:00.
And then, um, head out to the gyms.
[Bulger] Someone's living the Mexican-American dream.
translation.ko: 멕시코인의 아메리칸 드림을 이루며 살고 있네요

translation.en: I don't know if you wanna call it that, but let's say hard work pays off.
translation.ko: 적절한 표현인진 모르겠지만 어쨌든 고생 끝엔 낙이 오죠

translation.en: I mean, unfortunately,
I didn't realize I was a coach until almost ten years ago, you know.
translation.ko: 10년 전만 해도 제게 코치의 자질이 있단 걸 몰랐어요

translation.en: I wasted a lot of my time just...
doing nothing. Just working, you know.
Twenty-six years of my life in this place.
It is difficult to try to manage work and the kids.
translation.ko: 일과 아이들을 모두 신경 쓰는 건 힘들죠

translation.en: Yeah, I have, like, 30, 40 that compete.
And to train 30, 40 kids, it's hard.
It's hard.
And if I could do boxing 24/7, I would do this 24/7.
translation.ko: 매일 24시간 동안 권투만 할 수 있다면 좋겠죠

translation.en: But at this time,
making $200 every two months, three months, can't do it, can't do it.
You know?
B-Hop, he's been getting better and better and better.
And if B-Hop turns out the way we think he's gonna turn out...
four years I think I'll be out.
-Time to get to work. -[indistinct chatter and laughter]
[Colbert] I won my last amateur tournament.
So I was like, "Yeah, I'ma just go pro now. Time to go.
Waste no more time."
He wanna go to the Olympics. I'm not pressing to go to the Olympics.
translation.ko: 코치님은 올림픽에 나가라는데 전 별생각 없어요

translation.en: When I first started, I always wanted to be an Olympic coach.
translation.ko: 처음 일을 시작하면서 올림픽 코치가 되고 싶었죠

translation.en: Like, I want to be up there when...
At the Olympics, I want to be one of the head coaches of the United States.
translation.ko: 미국 대표팀 헤드 코치가 되고 싶어요

translation.en: [Colbert] I don't care about the Olympics. I never...
Like, that never was really my mindset, to go to Olympics.
My mindset was always to be world champion, to be rich, like Floyd Mayweather.
translation.ko: 플로이드 메이웨더처럼 부자 챔피언이 되고 싶었어요

translation.en: [Hopkins] Boxing and gold medal and being in Olympics
is dead in America right now.
Fighters, they look at Floyd Mayweather, they look how much money he's making.
translation.ko: 모두 플로이드 메이웨더처럼 돈 벌 생각만 하죠

translation.en: [scoffs] "Why would I go in Olympics and get nothing,
but maybe some sponsorship from Nike?
And I can go right to the pros,
and buy me a Bugatti."
Think about it.
[Bulger] The Olympics used to be where USA beat the crap out of the world,
translation.ko: “‘머니’ 플로이드 메이웨더” 예전엔 미국 대표팀이 “조지 포먼”

translation.en: where we proved we were the best boxers.
Winning the gold medal, nothing surpasses that.
There are people who can say, "I was a world champion professional boxer."
translation.ko: 월드 챔피언이었다고 말할 사람은 좀 있어도

translation.en: But to be an Olympic gold medal winner, very few people can say that.
translation.ko: 올림픽 금메달리스트였다고 할 수 있는 사람은 얼마 없죠

translation.en: It's the biggest prize that I've ever experienced.
[Bulger] But in 2012,
the US men's boxing team,
the team that's won more than any other country...
didn't win a single medal.
[announcer] The worst showing in history
of the storied United States of America Amateur Boxing Program.
[Oscar De La Hoya] In today's era of fighters, winning the gold
and having the responsibility of representing your country...
it's not in their mind anymore.
The passion is gone.
[Bulger] So the question is,
who has the ability and the desire
to get USA men's boxing back on the podium?
The answer is a lot more complicated than you might think.
[Awesome] I started boxing in about 2005.
translation.ko: 2005년에 권투에 입문했어요 “아마추어 선수 캠 F. 어썸”

translation.en: I was in 11th grade. 11th-12th grade, and I just did it for...
translation.ko: “아마추어 선수 캠 F. 어썸” 고2, 고3 때였어요

translation.en: just to lose weight.
Then I started fighting, and I just kept winning and winning and winning.
And I was like, "Ah, maybe this isn't that hard."
Tyler, step in.
[Bulger] Cam F. Awesome is America's all-time winningest amateur boxer.
translation.ko: 캠 F. 어썸은 미국 역사상 최다 우승 아마추어 선수입니다

translation.en: And his trainer, John Brown, is the president of USA Boxing.
translation.ko: 존 브라운 코치는 미국 권투계의 대통령이죠

translation.en: [John] To box for America,
you know, he gave up a lot,
because, unfortunately, the way our system is,
we don't have much money for these guys.
translation.ko: 받을 수 있는 지원금이 얼마 안 되거든요

translation.en: So now he has to live on $1,000 a month that USOC gives him.
translation.ko: 미국 올림픽 위원회가 주는 한 달 생계비가 천 달러예요

translation.en: And his fixed costs for his car,
his rent and his utilities is $900.
So that gives him $100 a month to live on.
I mean, I help him,
but he goes to the blood bank about once every two weeks and gives blood.
[Awesome] You do whatever you can for money. You pick up side jobs.
translation.ko: “펀치 뒤의 행동이 중요하다!” 돈을 벌려면 뭐든 해야죠 부업도 뛰고요

translation.en: You personal train people when you can, but it's pretty tough.
translation.ko: 개인 코치 일도 하지만 그래도 힘들어요

translation.en: A lot of people don't understand why I haven't turned pro.
translation.ko: 왜 프로로 전향하지 않는지 의아해하는 사람이 많죠

translation.en: My mission, my goal, my ambitions, it's not the money.
I want that feeling of sitting next to two dudes from other countries
who have to sit there and look happy
while they play my national anthem and I get a gold medal.
translation.ko: 전 금메달을 목에 걸고 우리나라 국가를 듣고 싶어요

translation.en: That's what I'm chasing. That's the dream that I want.
[Bulger] Cam should have had a shot at realizing his dream in 2012.
He qualified for the US Olympic Team, but then was suspended from competition
translation.ko: 대표팀 자격은 얻었지만 출전 자격을 정지당했죠

translation.en: when he failed to make himself available for drug tests.
I have to inform someone when I'm leaving town, and I didn't.
And that wasn't because I was doing any drugs or anything.
It's just I had so much going on in my life.
I was getting ready for the Olympics,
I was traveling, leaving the country.
Although I tested negative that same week that they were gonna drug test me,
translation.ko: 그 주에 시험을 봐서 음성 판정이 나오긴 했지만

translation.en: I still needed to inform them, and I messed up.
translation.ko: 그래도 미리 알려야 했어요 제 탓이죠

translation.en: During my suspension, I learned a lot about myself,
I learned a lot about the people around me.
I decided to legally change my name
and become a new person, new attitude, new way of life.
February 16, 2013, Lenroy Cameron Thompson Jr. died,
and then arose Cam F. Awesome.
[Bulger] With his new name, Cam F. Awesome is giving the Olympics one last shot.
translation.ko: 새로운 이름과 함께 올림픽에 마지막으로 도전합니다

translation.en: The road begins here, in Tennessee, at the first Olympic trials qualifier.
translation.ko: 이곳 테네시에서 여정이 처음으로 시작됩니다 “1일째 올림픽 선수 선발 대회”

translation.en: -[bell rings] -[man] Yeah, good work.
-[grunting] -[indistinct chatter]
[man 1] Good job! [man 2] Cam, you da man!
This guy is... To me, he box crazy...
translation.ko: 경기 방식은 유별나지만 어쨌든 항상 이겨요

translation.en: Crazy, but he wins.
translation.ko: 경기 방식은 유별나지만 어쨌든 항상 이겨요 “클라레사 쉴즈 2012 올림픽 금메달리스트”

translation.en: And everybody would be so mad and upset,
but he's like, "Cam F. Awesome. What do you expect?"
translation.ko: 캠 F. 어썸은 자신한테 뭘 기대했냐는 눈치죠

translation.en: People are like, "What is he doing? That's ugly. That... What?"
translation.ko: 다들 저게 무슨 짓이냐고 질색해요 “크리스 버드 전 헤비급 챔피언”

translation.en: They don't understand that kind of style, but the boxers he's fighting...
translation.ko: 그런 경기 방식을 관객은 이해 못 해도

translation.en: -[grunts] -...they understand it.
[announcer] Right, our winner, out of the blue corner, Cam Awesome.
translation.ko: 오늘의 승자는 청 코너 캠 어썸

translation.en: [Bulger] Cam F. Awesome got his first win tonight.
translation.ko: 캠 F. 어썸이 첫 승리를 거뒀습니다

translation.en: He'll have to fight three more times over the next three days
to earn a spot at the Olympic trials, a year from now, in Reno, Nevada.
translation.ko: 네바다 주 리노에서 열리는 선발전 참가 자격을 얻겠죠

translation.en: As if it wasn't difficult enough,
this road to the Olympics will be more dangerous than ever.
translation.ko: 올림픽을 향한 여정은 더 험난해지기만 합니다

translation.en: For the first time in 32 years,
Olympic competition is taking place without headgear.
They want to give you the pro atmosphere... right?
translation.ko: 프로 경기 같은 분위기를 원하는 거죠

translation.en: But the amateur benefits.
[Tom LeGan] We've been told that safety of the boxer is the primary concern.
translation.ko: 말로는 선수의 안전이 가장 중요하다고 해요

translation.en: There is a bit of a conflict with the no headgear.
translation.ko: 헤드기어 문제는 찬반 논란이 많아요 “톰 리건, 권투 코치”

translation.en: 'Cause, obviously, this wouldn't have happened without it.
[Bulger] There are two clear distinctions between amateur and professional boxing.
translation.ko: 아마추어와 프로 시합에는 두 가지 차이점이 있습니다

translation.en: Headgear and fighting for prize money.
Now, AIBA, the famously corrupt International Boxing Association,
translation.ko: 비리 많기로 소문난 국제 아마추어 복싱 연맹은

translation.en: wanna make the sport more entertaining.
But here's the thing.
If one of these fighters gets a bad cut,
even from something like an accidental head-butt,
they're out.
It's dangerous, and it's stupid.
It's not setting you up for the pros, it's fucking you up for the pros.
translation.ko: 프로 대우가 아니라 인생을 망치는 거예요

translation.en: You're losing a couple of brain cells before you even turn pro.
[De La Hoya] If I didn't have headgear, and I was getting cut,
and beat up, and bruised up, and knocked out,
I would turn pro. I mean, might as well get paid for it.
translation.ko: 차라리 전 프로가 되겠어요 돈이라도 벌잖아요

translation.en: [John] You know, even pros don't fight five days in a row.
Maybe the best guy doesn't win all the time,
whoever's the luckiest wins. That doesn't get head-butted.
